title: STAT 244-SC
text:
üîç Final Project: Predicting Customer Churn with Logistic and LASSO Regression
This project uses machine learning to address a core economic problem: customer retention. I built logistic and LASSO regression models to predict whether a bank customer will churn based on features like balance, age, activity status, and gender. Using 10-fold cross-validation and ROC-AUC for evaluation, I compared model performance and explored how LASSO can select the most economically meaningful predictors. The results provide actionable insights for firms aiming to reduce churn and improve customer lifetime value.

data <- read.csv('Bank Customer Churn Prediction.csv')
head(data)

  customer_id credit_score country gender age tenure   balance products_number
1    15634602          619  France Female  42      2      0.00               1
2    15647311          608   Spain Female  41      1  83807.86               1
3    15619304          502  France Female  42      8 159660.80               3
4    15701354          699  France Female  39      1      0.00               2
5    15737888          850   Spain Female  43      2 125510.82               1
6    15574012          645   Spain   Male  44      8 113755.78               2
  credit_card active_member estimated_salary churn
1           1             1        101348.88     1
2           0             1        112542.58     0
3           1             0        113931.57     1
4           0             0         93826.63     0
5           1             1         79084.10     0
6           1             0        149756.71     1



data %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = churn, fill = country)) + 
  geom_bar(position = "dodge") +
  labs(x = 'Churn?', y = 'Counts', fill = 'Country') + 
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("steelblue", "lightblue", "darkblue")) + 
  theme_classic()
